alfredsnippet.snippet:
Arthur Custance, The Doorway Papers. http://www.custance.org/

"... all too frequently the most obvious solutions to the simplest of problems stare us in the face, but we quite fail to observe them. After one has the solution, it tends to appear very obvious indeed. Before one has the solution, it is far from obvious. My own experience in a research laboratory has strongly confirmed in my mind the fact that most of us see things pretty much as they are and have little or no power to envision possibilities which are not foreshadowed in the immediate present. We all tend to be great critics of what is, and a few are able to act as improvers, but the man who can produce genuine innovations is rare."
alfredsnippet.name: Phys.org Post - Most of Us Lack an Ability to Envision Possbilities
